contentrichtext.text: A '''Yojana''' (Sanskrit : योजन ) is a [[Vedic civilization|Vedic]] measure of distance used in ancient [[India]]. The exact measurement is disputed amongst scholars with distances being given between 6 to 15 [[kilometer]]s (4 to 9 [[mile]]s). In modern [[Nepali language|Nepali]] and [[Hindi]] ''yojana'' (Hindi : योजना ) also means "plan" or blueprint and has an interesting connection with the Cartesian notion of distance. However "Yojana'" (याेजन) and "Yojanaa" (याेजना - meaning "Plan") are different. They are pronounced differently. Difference is "a" and "aa" at the end, the second one pronounced "aa" as in arm [ārm]. ==Variations on length== The length of the Yojana varied depending on the different standards adopted by different [[Indian astronomy|Indian astronomers]]. It was taken to be the distance covered by an ox cart in one day. In the ''[[Surya Siddhanta]]'' of the 5th century, for example, a Yojana was equivalent to 5 miles,<ref name=Thompson>{{citation|title=Planetary Diameters in the Surya-Siddhanta|author=[[Richard Thompson]]|journal=[[Journal of Scientific Exploration]]|volume=11|issue=2|pages=193–200 [196]|year=1997}}</ref> and the same was true for [[Aryabhata]]'s ''[[Aryabhatiya]]'' (499).<ref>{{MacTutor Biography|id=Aryabhata_I|title=Aryabhata I}}</ref> By the time of [[Paramesvara]] in the 14th century, the Yojana was more than 1.5 times larger than it was in Aryabhata's time, thus a Yojana was equivalent to at least 8 miles by Paramesvara's time.<ref name=Thompson/> Religious leader [[A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]] gives the equivalent length of a yojana as 8 miles ('''12,8 km''') <ref>[http://vedabase.net/sb/10/57/18/en1 Srimad Bhagavatam 10.57.18 (translation)] "one yojana measures about eight miles"</ref> throughout his translations of the [[Bhagavata Purana]]. Some traditional Indian scholars give measurements between 13 km and 16 km (8-10 miles) or thereabouts.{{Fact|date=February 2007}} Alexander Cunningham, in ''The Ancient Geography of India'', takes a yojana to mean 8 miles. ==Usage== Height of meru parvat is estimated to be 1,00,000 yojan in jain cosmology where 1 yojan is given as 4000 miles. If the length of a ''Yojana'' is taken to be approximately 8 to 10 miles (13-16 km), like it was in later times, then its subsidiary measurements are as follows: *1 angula = 16 mm to 21 mm *4 angulas = one dhanu graha (bow grip) = 62 mm to 83 mm; *8 angulas = one dhanu musti (fist with thumb raised) = 125 mm to 167 mm; *12 angulas = 1 vitasti ([[Span_(unit)|handspan]]: distance between tip of thumb and tip of last finger when palm is stretched) = 188 mm to 250 mm *2 vitastis = 1 aratni (cubit) = 375 mm to 500 mm *4 aratnis = 1 danda = 1.5 to 2.0 m *2 dandas = 1 dhanu = 3 to 4 m *5 dhanus = 1 rajju = 15 m to 20 m *2 rajjus = 1 paridesha = 30 m to 40 m *100 parideshas = 1 krosha (or gorata) = 3 km to 4 km *4 kroshas = 1 yojana = 13 km to 16 km *1,000 yojanas = 1 Mahayojan = 13 Mm to 16 Mm ==See also== *[[Hindu cosmology]] *[[List of numbers in Hindu scriptures]] *[[Palya]] *[[Rajju]] *[[Religious cosmology]] *[[Vikas yojna]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *''The Artha Shaastra of Kautilya'', [[Penguin Books]] *[http://www.valmikiramayan.net/bala/sarga5/bala_5_prose.htm Valmiki Ramayana] </div> [[Category:Customary units in India]] [[Category:Hindu astronomy]] [[Category:Obsolete units of measurement]] [[Category:Units of length]] {{SAsia-hist-stub}} {{measurement-stub}}
